disclosures.quote: Aqueous Film-Forming Foams. Approximately 5,000 cases remain filed against 3M and other defendants, including EIDP and Chemours, and some including Corteva and DuPont, alleging personal injury (primarily prostate, kidney, and testicular cancer) from the use of aqueous film-forming foams (“AFFF”) and consolidated in a multi-district litigation proceeding in federal district court in South Carolina (“SC MDL”). Most of these recent cases also assert claims that the EIDP and Chemours separation constituted a fraudulent conveyance. The SC MDL ordered the dismissal of plaintiff claims by September 10, 2024, without prejudice, if such plaintiff could not produce peer reviewed science and expert reports supporting PFAS as both the general and specific causation of their personal injury. The first bellwether personal injury trial is expected to begin in October 2025. Additionally, in December 2023, a class action was filed in Canada against 3M and other defendants, including EIDP and Chemours, alleging PFOS and PFOA environmental contamination and personal injury from use of AFFF.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page F-39, Note 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities - Aqueous Film-Forming Foams

disclosures.quote: New York. EIDP is a defendant in a putative class action (the "Baker Class Action"), brought by persons who live in and around Hoosick Falls, New York. These lawsuits assert claims for medical monitoring, property damage and personal injury based on alleged PFOA releases from manufacturing facilities owned and operated by co-defendants in Hoosick Falls. The lawsuits allege that EIDP and others supplied materials used at these facilities resulting in PFOA air and water contamination. A court approved settlement was reached between the plaintiffs and the other co-defendants regarding the Baker Class Action case. In September 2022, the class certification of the Baker Class Action was granted, with the court certifying three separate classes consisting of a private well property damage class, a medical monitoring class and a nuisance class. The trial for the Baker Class Action is expected to begin in July 2025.

disclosures.quote: Continuing political and social attention to climate change and its impacts has resulted in regulatory and market-based approaches to limit greenhouse gas emissions. The company believes there is a way forward for sustainable climate change mitigation that both enables farmers to meet the demands of a growing population and secures the economic future for the vast majority of the world’s population who depend on agriculture for their livelihoods. While Corteva is working to reduce its role in the emission of greenhouse gasses, it also invests in enabling innovation that can create a more resilient agriculture value chain. The company engages with multiple stakeholders and partners around the globe regarding our innovations and actionable ideas to help safeguard the health and well-being of the planet and its people.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that reduced soil fertility caused by its pesticides is a risk to the business? disclosures.quote: The costs of complying with evolving regulatory requirements could negatively impact Corteva’s business, results of operations and financial condition. Actual or alleged violations of environmental laws or permit requirements could result in restrictions or prohibitions on plant operations, substantial civil or criminal sanctions, as well as the assessment of strict liability and/or joint and several liability. Corteva is subject to extensive federal, state, local and foreign laws, regulations, rules and ordinances relating to pollution, protection of the environment, waste water discharges, the generation, storage, handling, transportation, treatment, disposal and remediation of hazardous substances and waste materials and the use of genetically modified seeds and crop protection active ingredients by growers. Environmental and health and safety laws, regulations and standards, including those with respect to PFAS and other substances, expose Corteva to the risk of substantial costs and liabilities, including liabilities associated with Corteva’s business and the discontinued and divested businesses and operations of EIDP. As is typical for businesses like Corteva’s, soil and groundwater contamination has occurred in the past at certain sites and may be identified at other sites in the future. Disposal of waste from Corteva’s business at off-site locations also exposes it to potential remediation costs. Consistent with past practice, these sites continue to be monitored, investigated and remediated for soil and groundwater contamination, as applicable.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 13, Item 1A. Risk Factors

disclosures.quote: Corteva’s business, results of operations and financial condition could be adversely affected by environmental, litigation and other commitments and contingencies. As a result of Corteva’s operations, including past operations and those related to divested businesses and discontinued operations of EIDP, Corteva incurs environmental operating costs for pollution abatement activities including waste collection and disposal, installation and maintenance of air pollution controls and wastewater treatment, emissions testing and monitoring and obtaining permits. Corteva also incurs environmental operating costs related to environmental related research and development activities including environmental field and treatment studies as well as toxicity and degradation testing to evaluate the environmental impact of products and raw materials. In addition, Corteva maintains and periodically reviews and adjusts its accruals for probable environmental remediation and restoration costs.

disclosures.quote: Accruals for environmental matters are recorded when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount of the liability can be reasonably estimated. At December 31, 2024, the company had accrued obligations of $478 million for probable environmental remediation and restoration costs, including $46 million for the remediation of Superfund sites. As remediation activities vary substantially in duration and cost from site to site, it is difficult to develop precise estimates of future site remediation costs. The company's estimates are based on a number of factors, including the complexity of the geology, the nature and extent of contamination, the type of remedy, the outcome of discussions with regulatory agencies and other Potentially Responsible Parties ("PRPs") at multi-party sites and the number of and financial viability of other PRPs. Therefore, considerable uncertainty exists with respect to environmental remediation and costs, and, under adverse changes in circumstances, the potential liability may range up to approximately $600 million above the accrued obligations amount. Consequently, it is reasonably possible that environmental remediation and restoration costs in excess of amounts accrued could have a material impact on the company’s results of operations, financial condition and cash flows. It is the opinion of the company’s management, however, that the possibility is remote that costs in excess of the range disclosed will have a material impact on the company’s results of operations, financial condition or cash flows.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 51-52, Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis - Environmental Matters
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet provides explicit financial details for 'accrued obligations of $478 million for probable environmental remediation and restoration costs,' and states a 'potential liability may range up to approximately $600 million above the accrued obligations amount.' It also states that these costs 'could have a material impact on the company’s results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.' While it doesn't specifically mention 'reduced soil fertility caused by pesticides,' environmental remediation costs often relate to soil contamination, which impacts soil health, and this clearly links environmental risks to financial materiality.

disclosures.quote: Netherlands. In April 2021, four municipalities in the Netherlands filed complaints alleging contamination of land and groundwater resulting from the emission of PFOA and GenX by Corteva, DuPont and Chemours. The municipalities seek to recover costs incurred due to the alleged emissions, including damages for investigation costs, construction project delays, depreciation of land, soil remediation, liabilities to contractors, and attorneys’ fees. In September 2023, the court entered a second interlocutory judgment, ruling, inter alia, that defendants were liable to the municipalities for PFOA emissions during a certain time period, and the removal costs of deposited emissions on the municipalities land infringes their property rights by an objective standard. In June 2024, Chemours and these Dutch municipalities signed a letter of intent that included the implementation of a specific remediation plan for the restoration of restricted vegetable gardens in certain areas of those municipalities to be funded by Chemours, sampling and developing a program to address a recreational lake, and further settlement discussions, including a potential fund to cover certain other expenditures aimed at environmental-related activities. While the letter of intent contemplates the possibility of settlement, discussions between the parties related to the resolution to these matters remain ongoing. Although the company believes a loss is probable, it is not estimable at this time due to various reasons including, among others, that such discussions remain in their early stages. As of December 31, 2024, an accrual has been established for the estimated environmental remediation set forth in the letter of intent.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page F-42, Note 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities - Netherlands
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly details 'complaints alleging contamination of land and groundwater' and mentions 'soil remediation' costs. The court ruled defendants were liable for PFOA emissions and 'removal costs of deposited emissions on the municipalities land.' An accrual has been established for estimated environmental remediation, clearly linking soil contamination (a form of reduced soil fertility/health) to a financial risk, though the specific amount of Corteva's accrual is not quantified here.

categorization.financial_justification: The snippet mentions 'costs incurred,' 'damages,' and 'soil remediation' and states that 'an accrual has been established,' indicating financial impacts, but does not provide specific financial figures for Corteva's portion of these costs or a definitive statement about their materiality.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet refers to past complaints ('April 2021'), a court judgment ('September 2023'), a letter of intent ('June 2024'), and ongoing discussions and accruals, indicating a 'Multiple or Unclear' timeframe.

disclosures.quote: The company operates global manufacturing, product handling and distribution facilities that are subject to a broad array of environmental laws and regulations. Such rules are subject to change by the implementing governmental agency, and the company monitors these changes closely. Company policy requires that all operations fully meet or exceed legal and regulatory requirements. In addition, the company implements voluntary programs to reduce air emissions, minimize the generation of hazardous waste, decrease the volume of water use and discharges, increase the efficiency of energy use and reduce the generation of persistent, bioaccumulative and toxic materials. Management has noted a global upward trend in the amount and complexity of proposed chemicals regulation. The costs to comply with complex environmental laws and regulations, as well as internal voluntary programs and goals, are significant and will continue to be significant for the foreseeable future.

disclosures.quote: Corteva faces risks arising from various unasserted and asserted litigation matters arising out of the normal course of its current and former business operations, including intellectual property, commercial, product liability, environmental and antitrust lawsuits. Corteva has noted a trend in public and private suits being filed on behalf of states, counties, cities and utilities alleging harm to the general public and the environment, including waterways and watersheds. Claims alleging harm to the public and the environment may be brought against Corteva, notwithstanding years of scientific evidence and regulatory determinations supporting the safety of crop protection products. The litigation involving Monsanto’s Roundup® non-selective glyphosate containing weedkiller products has resulted in negative publicity and sentiment and may lead to similar suits with respect to glyphosate-containing products and/or other established crop protection products. Claims and allegations that Corteva’s products or products that Corteva manufactures or markets on behalf of third parties are not safe could result in litigation, damage to Corteva’s reputation and have a material adverse effect on Corteva’s business.

disclosures.quote: The degree of public understanding and acceptance or perceived public acceptance of Corteva’s biotechnology and other agricultural products and technologies can affect Corteva’s sales and results of operations by affecting planting approvals, regulatory requirements and customer purchase decisions. Concerns and claims regarding the safe use of seeds with biotechnology traits and crop protection products in general, and their potential impact on health and the environment reflect a growing trend in societal demands for increasing levels of product safety and environmental protection. These and other concerns could manifest themselves in delays or failures in obtaining or retaining regulatory approvals, delayed product launches, lack of market acceptance, product discontinuation, litigation, continued pressure for and adoption of more stringent regulatory intervention, termination of raw material supply agreements, legal claims, preferred purchases and stockholder proposals. These and other concerns could also influence public perceptions, the viability or continued sales of certain of Corteva’s products, Corteva’s reputation and the cost to comply with regulations. As a result, such concerns could have a material adverse effect on Corteva’s business, results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.

disclosures.quote: As of December 31, 2024, the company has been notified of potential liability under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act ("Superfund") or similar state laws at 507 sites around the U.S., including approximately 100 sites for which the company does not believe it has liability based on current information. Active remediation is under way at approximately 60 of the 507 sites. In addition, the company has resolved its liability at about 212 sites, either by completing remedial actions with other PRPs or by participating in "de minimis buyouts" with other PRPs whose waste, like the company's, represented only a small fraction of the total waste present at a site. There were no new notices in 2024 and two new notices in 2023.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that loss of pollinators and beneficial insects, such as bees, is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: Beginning in January 2022, before registering any new conventional pesticide active ingredient, the EPA evaluates the potential effects on listed species and their designated critical habitats under the Endangered Species Act (the “ESA”). The EPA also has initiated such evaluations for certain other active ingredients in response to existing or threatened litigation. Where the EPA determines that a pesticide in the registration and re-evaluation processes “may affect” a listed species, the EPA must consult with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Marine Fisheries Service. As part of its approval, registration, and reevaluation processes, the EPA may impose certain use restrictions on crop protection products under the ESA. When the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Marine Fisheries Service add additional listed specifies, the EPA may initiate new ESA evaluations. Under the citizen suit provisions, the ESA also includes citizen suit provisions that allow the public to bring suit in court against federal agencies when they believe a listed species is not being adequately protected by the EPA. FIFRA contains similar provisions that allow the public to challenge an EPA’s registration decision. These lawsuits may subject products to additional use limitations and labeling requirements and further studies, as well as result in registrations being revoked, in whole or in part.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 27, Regulatory Considerations
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet clearly identifies the potential for regulatory actions (use restrictions, labeling requirements, revoked registrations) and lawsuits due to the 'potential effects on listed species' under the Endangered Species Act. While 'pollinators and beneficial insects' are not explicitly named, 'listed species' is a broad category that includes them, and the consequences described directly impact the business's ability to sell products, thus constituting a clear business risk. It describes the nature of the risk and its potential operational impacts.

categorization.framing_justification: The language explicitly discusses 'potential effects on listed species,' 'use restrictions,' 'labeling requirements,' 'registrations being revoked,' and 'lawsuits,' all of which represent negative consequences or threats to the business's operations and product viability. This clearly frames the issue as a risk.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure outlines potential business impacts such as 'use limitations,' 'labeling requirements,' 'further studies,' and 'registrations being revoked,' which imply financial consequences (e.g., lost sales, increased costs). However, it does not provide any specific monetary values or a definitive statement about the financial materiality of these impacts, making it non-financial.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet refers to ongoing regulatory evaluations ('EPA evaluates,' 'EPA has initiated'), re-evaluation processes, and potential future actions ('EPA may impose,' 'may subject products,' 'result in registrations being revoked'). This indicates a present-day and forward-looking time horizon for the described risks.

annotations.notes: Doesn't mention bees explicitly but they would fall under the protected species as pollinators

disclosures.quote: In fact, 100% of the newly-developed Corteva solutions in our pipeline meet at least one of our stringent sustainability criteria, which range from increasing water use efficiency to protecting biodiversity and ecosystems, while also offering improvements in product performance as compared to those in the market today.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that rising compliance, testing, registration, or re-registration costs related to their products is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: The regulatory approval processes and procedures globally are becoming increasingly more complex, which has resulted in additional testing needs, longer approval timelines that are difficult to predict, and higher development and maintenance costs. We continue to invest on an ongoing basis to keep dossiers current, respond to regulators and meet evolving regulatory standards required by global regulatory frameworks. Failure to comply with these regulations or future regulatory bans and requirements related to our products and their use may materially impact our financial performance. The increase in timelines for regulatory approvals may result in the company not achieving its sustainability targets, or its anticipated returns on research and development investments.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 27, Regulatory Considerations

disclosures.quote: Seed products incorporating biotechnology derived traits and crop protection products must be extensively tested for safety, efficacy and environmental impact before they can be registered for production, use, sale or commercialization in a given market. In certain jurisdictions, Corteva must periodically renew its approvals for both biotechnology and crop protection products, which typically require Corteva to demonstrate compliance with then-current standards which generally are more stringent since the prior registration. The regulatory approvals process is lengthy, costly, complex and in some markets unpredictable, with requirements that can vary by product, technology, industry and country. The regulatory approvals process for products that incorporate novel modes of action or new technologies can be particularly unpredictable and uncertain due to the then-current state of regulatory guidelines and objectives, as well as governmental policy considerations and non- governmental organization and other stakeholder considerations. The uncertainty and increased length of regulatory approvals may reduce Corteva’s return on its research and development investments, and impede its ability to meet sales, profitability, or sustainability metrics.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that class action lawsuits and legal challenges from health/environmental claims as a result of direct or indirect exposure to their products is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: As of December 31, 2024, there were pending asserted claims for personal injury against the former Dow Agrosciences LLC, alleging injuries related to chlorpyrifos exposure, the active ingredient in Lorsban®, an insecticide used by commercial farms for field fruit, nut and vegetable crops. Corteva ended its production of Lorsban® in 2020. Chlorpyrifos products are restricted-use pesticides, which are not available for purchase or use by the general public, and may only be sold to, and used by, certified applicators or someone under the certified applicator's direct supervision. These lawsuits do not relate to Dursban®, a residential type chlorpyrifos product that was authorized for indoor purposes, which was discontinued over two decades ago prior to the Merger and Corteva’s formation and Separation. Claimants allege personal injury, including autism, developmental delays and/or decreased neurologic function, resulting from farm worker exposure and bystander drift and in utero exposure to chlorpyrifos. Certain claimants have also put forth remediation claims due to alleged property contamination from chlorpyrifos. As of December 31, 2024, an accrual has been established for the estimated resolution of certain claims.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 42, NOTE 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly details 'pending asserted claims for personal injury' and 'remediation claims due to alleged property contamination' related to the Lorsban® product. It states that 'an accrual has been established for the estimated resolution of certain claims,' which indicates that the company has assessed the financial impact and deemed a loss probable and estimable, thus providing a full disclosure of the risk's financial materiality.

disclosures.quote: Corteva faces risks arising from various unasserted and asserted litigation matters arising out of the normal course of its current and former business operations, including intellectual property, commercial, product liability, environmental and antitrust lawsuits. Corteva has noted a trend in public and private suits being filed on behalf of states, counties, cities and utilities alleging harm to the general public and the environment, including waterways and watersheds. Claims alleging harm to the public and the environment may be brought against Corteva, notwithstanding years of scientific evidence and regulatory determinations supporting the safety of crop protection products. The litigation involving Monsanto’s Roundup® non-selective glyphosate containing weedkiller products has resulted in negative publicity and sentiment and may lead to similar suits with respect to glyphosate-containing products and/or other established crop protection products. Claims and allegations that Corteva’s products or products that Corteva manufactures or markets on behalf of third parties are not safe could result in litigation, damage to Corteva’s reputation and have a material adverse effect on Corteva’s business. It is not possible to predict the outcome of these various proceedings and any potential impact on Corteva. An adverse outcome in any one or more of these matters may result in losses not fully covered by Corteva's insurance policies, and could be material to Corteva's financial results. Various factors or developments can lead to changes in current estimates of liabilities. Such factors and developments may include, but are not limited to, additional data, safety or risk assessments, as well as a final adverse judgment, significant settlement or changes in applicable law. A future adverse ruling or unfavorable development could result in future charges that could have a material adverse effect on Corteva.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 33, Risks Related to Our Operations

This provides a definitive statement about the financial materiality of such legal challenges.

disclosures.quote: In April 2021, four municipalities in the Netherlands filed complaints alleging contamination of land and groundwater resulting from the emission of PFOA and GenX by Corteva, DuPont and Chemours. The municipalities seek to recover costs incurred due to the alleged emissions, including damages for investigation costs, construction project delays, depreciation of land, soil remediation, liabilities to contractors, and attorneys’ fees. In September 2023, the court entered a second interlocutory judgment, ruling, inter alia, that defendants were liable to the municipalities for PFOA emissions during a certain time period, and the removal costs of deposited emissions on the municipalities land infringes their property rights by an objective standard. In June 2024, Chemours and these Dutch municipalities signed a letter of intent that included the implementation of a specific remediation plan for the restoration of restricted vegetable gardens in certain areas of those municipalities to be funded by Chemours, sampling and developing a program to address a recreational lake, and further settlement discussions, including a potential fund to cover certain other expenditures aimed at environmental-related activities. While the letter of intent contemplates the possibility of settlement, discussions between the parties related to the resolution to these matters remain ongoing. Although the company believes a loss is probable, it is not estimable at this time due to various reasons including, among others, that such discussions remain in their early stages. As of December 31, 2024, an accrual has been established for the estimated environmental remediation set forth in the letter of intent. Additionally, the Office of Public Prosecutor in the Netherlands opened a criminal investigation against certain Dutch subsidiaries of Chemours and Historical DuPont, as well as each subsidiary's directors, alleging unlawful PFOA and GenX emissions from Chemours' Dordrecht Works facility.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 43, NOTE 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities

It also mentions a 'criminal investigation' and states that 'an accrual has been established for the estimated environmental remediation.' The establishment of an accrual indicates that the company has assessed the financial impact and deemed a loss probable and estimable, thus providing a full disclosure of the risk's financial materiality.

This clearly frames the issue as a risk.

disclosures.quote: Accruals for environmental matters are recorded when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount of the liability can be reasonably estimated. At December 31, 2024, the company had accrued obligations of $478 million for probable environmental remediation and restoration costs, including $46 million for the remediation of Superfund sites. As remediation activities vary substantially in duration and cost from site to site, it is difficult to develop precise estimates of future site remediation costs. The company's estimates are based on a number of factors, including the complexity of the geology, the nature and extent of contamination, the type of remedy, the outcome of discussions with regulatory agencies and other Potentially Responsible Parties ("PRPs") at multi-party sites and the number of and financial viability of other PRPs. Therefore, considerable uncertainty exists with respect to environmental remediation and costs, and, under adverse changes in circumstances, it is reasonably possible that the ultimate cost with respect to these particular matters could range up to approximately $600 million above the accrued obligations amount. Consequently, it is reasonably possible that environmental remediation and restoration costs in excess of amounts accrued could have a material impact on the company’s results of operations, financial condition and cash flows. It is the opinion of the company’s management, however, that the possibility is remote that costs in excess of the range disclosed will have a material impact on the company’s results of operations, financial condition or cash flows.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 44, NOTE 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet provides a comprehensive disclosure of accrued environmental liabilities, stating 'accrued obligations of $478 million for probable environmental remediation and restoration costs, including $46 million for the remediation of Superfund sites.' It also quantifies a potential exposure of 'approximately $600 million above the accrued obligations amount' and explicitly states that these costs 'could have a material impact on the company’s results of operations, financial condition and cash flows.' This provides a definitive statement about the financial materiality of environmental claims and their associated costs.

disclosures.quote: Approximately 5,000 cases remain filed against 3M and other defendants, including EIDP and Chemours, and some including Corteva and DuPont, alleging personal injury (primarily prostate, kidney, and testicular cancer) from the use of aqueous film-forming foams (“AFFF”) and consolidated in a multi-district litigation proceeding in federal district court in South Carolina (“SC MDL”). Most of these recent cases also assert claims that the EIDP and Chemours separation constituted a fraudulent conveyance. The SC MDL ordered the dismissal of plaintiff claims by September 10, 2024, without prejudice, if such plaintiff could not produce peer reviewed science and expert reports supporting PFAS as both the general and specific causation of their personal injury. The first bellwether personal injury trial is expected to begin in October 2025. Additionally, in December 2023, a class action was filed in Canada against 3M and other defendants, including EIDP and Chemours, alleging PFOS and PFOA environmental contamination and personal injury from use of AFFF.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 42, NOTE 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities

disclosures.quote: As discussed below and in Note 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities, to the Consolidated Financial Statements, certain of the environmental proceedings and litigation allocated to Corteva as part of the Separation from DuPont relate to the legacy EIDP businesses, including their use of PFOA, which, for purposes of this report, means collectively perfluorooctanoic acid and its salts, including the ammonium salt and does not distinguish between the two forms, and PFAS, which means per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, including PFOA, PFOS (perfluorooctanesulfonic acid), GenX and other perfluorinated chemicals and compounds ("PFCs"). This litigation includes multiple natural resource damage lawsuits across the United States filed by municipalities and alleging PFOA contamination, as well as, lawsuits by four municipalities in the Netherlands alleging contamination of land and groundwater resulting from the emission of PFOA and GenX by Corteva, DuPont and Chemours.

disclosures.quote: On June 1, 2023, Corteva, EIDP, Inc., DuPont, and Chemours (collectively, the “settling companies”) entered into a binding agreement in principle to comprehensively resolve all drinking water claims related to PFAS of a defined class of U.S. public water systems that serve the vast majority of the United States population, including, but not limited to the AFFF claims in the SC MDL Nationwide Water District Settlement. PFAS, as defined in the settlement, includes PFOA and HFPO-DA, among a broad range of fluorinated organic substances. The Nationwide Water District Settlement was entered into solely by way of compromise and settlement and is not in any way an admission of liability or fault by Corteva or EIDP.

disclosures.quote: EIDP is a defendant in a putative class action (the "Baker Class Action"), brought by persons who live in and around Hoosick Falls, New York. These lawsuits assert claims for medical monitoring, property damage and personal injury based on alleged PFOA releases from manufacturing facilities owned and operated by co-defendants in Hoosick Falls. The lawsuits allege that EIDP and others supplied materials used at these facilities resulting in PFOA air and water contamination. A court approved settlement was reached between the plaintiffs and the other co-defendants regarding the Baker Class Action case. In September 2022, the class certification of the Baker Class Action was granted, with the court certifying three separate classes consisting of a private well property damage class, a medical monitoring class and a nuisance class. The trial for the Baker Class Action is expected to begin in July 2025.
disclosures.source: corteva_ars_2025.pdf, Page 43, NOTE 16 - Commitments and Contingent Liabilities

disclosures.quote: In addition to the natural resource damage cases in New Jersey and New York, natural resource damage filed lawsuits against EIDP, Chemours, and others, claiming, among other things, PFC (including PFOA) contamination of groundwater and drinking water, have been filed by 31 state attorneys general, the District of Columbia and three U.S. territories. Certain cases also name DuPont and Corteva as defendants and include claims of fraudulent conveyance. The complaints seek reimbursement for past and future costs to investigate and remediate the alleged contamination and compensation for the loss of value and use of the state’s natural resources. Due to overlapping AFFF allegations, virtually all of these cases have been transferred, or are pending transfer to the SC MDL. These cases are largely in the discovery phase. While the recent mediation of the natural resource case in North Carolina and New Jersey concluded without resolution, discussions continue between the parties to seek a resolution.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that soil degradation caused by its fertiliser products is a risk to the business? Fertilisers impact soil degradation by worsening the soil structure, thereby reducing water infiltration and retention, which increases erosion.

disclosures.quote: Soil Degradation: Soil degradation affects global food security with significant environmental implications. It is estimated that by 2050 90% of the planet land’s surface could be degraded, primarily due to soil erosion, nutrient depletion, loss of biodiversity, and pollution. With poor farming techniques exacerbating the problem, many farmers are now focusing on soil health and regenerative agriculture by adopting sustainable farming techniques that improve soil structure, increase carbon sequestration, and promote biodiversity.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 17, Our Operating Environment
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet acknowledges soil degradation as a global issue and mentions its environmental implications and impact on food security. It discusses farmers' focus on soil health and regenerative agriculture, but it does not explicitly link soil degradation as a risk to Fertiglobe's business specifically caused by its fertilizer products. The disclosure remains at a high, industry-wide level without direct business impact from its products.

categorization.framing_justification: The language describes a global environmental and food security issue without framing it as a direct threat or advantage specifically for Fertiglobe's business operations or products. It presents factual information about a megatrend.
categorization.financial_justification: The snippet discusses environmental implications and global estimates but provides no explicit financial values, costs, or statements about financial materiality for the company.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet refers to an estimation 'by 2050' for land degradation, indicating a future-oriented perspective on the issue, although it also describes current trends in farming practices.

annotations.notes: Statement on farmers issues with soil fertility but doesn't link to buisness risk.

disclosures.quote: Through various programs, we work with our customers around the world to maximize yields, strengthen crops, prevent soil degradation, promote sustainable agricultural practices, and accelerate growth to meet the world’s rising food demands.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 71, Product Stewardship
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet states that Fertiglobe works to 'prevent soil degradation' through its programs, positioning its efforts as a solution. While it acknowledges soil degradation as an issue relevant to agriculture, it does not disclose that soil degradation *caused by its fertilizer products* is a risk to its business. Instead, it highlights its positive contributions.

categorization.framing_justification: The disclosure frames the company's actions and programs as beneficial, aiming to 'prevent soil degradation' and 'promote sustainable agricultural practices,' which presents the topic as an area of positive contribution and value creation.
categorization.financial_justification: The snippet describes qualitative efforts and positive impacts without providing any explicit financial figures, costs, or statements regarding financial materiality.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The statement uses present tense verbs like 'work' and 'promote,' indicating ongoing activities and current commitments to sustainable practices.

annotations.notes: Statement on pratises to maintain soil fertility but doesn't link to buisness risk.

disclosures.quote: If removals by yields are not adequately replaced, soil health will decline and eventually lead to soil degradation and loss of soil health. Reduction of yields increases the risk of agricultural expansion into previously uncultivated land. To prevent this land encroachment, further loss of biodiversity, and the release of sequestered carbon, it is crucial to supply existing agricultural land with a sufficient amount of nutrients.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 71, Product Stewardship
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet discusses the negative consequences of *not* replacing soil nutrients, which can lead to soil degradation. It then argues that supplying 'sufficient amount of nutrients' (i.e., fertilizers) is 'crucial' to prevent these negative outcomes. This frames fertilizers as a solution to prevent soil degradation, rather than acknowledging them as a cause or a business risk.

categorization.framing_justification: The disclosure frames the supply of nutrients (fertilizers) as a crucial solution to prevent negative outcomes like soil degradation and biodiversity loss, thereby presenting it as a beneficial and value-creating aspect of the business.
categorization.financial_justification: The snippet describes potential ecological and agricultural consequences but does not include any explicit financial figures, costs, or statements about financial materiality for the company.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The language discusses future scenarios ('will decline,' 'increases the risk') and the ongoing necessity ('is crucial') to prevent these, indicating a forward-looking perspective on potential impacts and mitigation.

annotations.notes: Statement on pratises to maintain soil fertility and farming issues but doesn't link to buisness risk.

It does not characterize them as a risk to the business, which is required for a PARTIAL classification. The current justification relies on inference ('implies a business risk') rather than the text itself.

categorization.framing_justification: The disclosure mentions 'carbon taxes' as a driver for change in the fertilizer sector, which is typically viewed as a cost or threat that businesses must address, thus framing it as a risk.
categorization.financial_justification: The snippet mentions 'carbon taxes' but does not provide any explicit financial figures, costs, or statements about the financial materiality of these taxes for the company.

It does not characterize CBAM as a risk. The classification should be UNCLEAR as the topic is acknowledged but not framed as a risk.

This is a direct acknowledgment of a market trend (related to alternatives and potentially organic farming) that poses a risk to the business by potentially reducing demand for its products. However, it does not provide specific financial figures or a statement of financial materiality.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that restoration of contaminated manufacturing sites is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: With respect to asset retirement obligations, the Group recognizes a provision if the Group has an obligation to restore a leased asset in its original condition at the end of its lease term and in case of legal requirements with respect to clean up of contamination of land, and the estimate can be made reliably. Based on the land lease terms of the Group's production facilities, some entities in the Group have the obligation to restore their site upon decommissioning. The Group has not recorded a liability for this asset retirement obligation, as it does not believe there is currently a reasonable basis for estimating a date or range of dates of cessation of the operations, which is necessary to estimate the fair value of this liability.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 170, Notes to the consolidated Financial Statements, Note 5, Critical accounting judgments, estimates and assumptions - Provisions
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly states that the Group has an 'obligation to restore a leased asset in its original condition' and 'legal requirements with respect to clean up of contamination of land' for its 'production facilities' upon decommissioning. It also clearly states that 'The Group has not recorded a liability for this asset retirement obligation' due to the inability to reliably estimate the cessation date. This acknowledges the existence of the obligation (risk) and its potential financial nature, but without quantification, making it a partial disclosure.

categorization.framing_justification: The language 'obligation to restore' and 'legal requirements with respect to clean up of contamination of land' frames this as a potential negative consequence or liability for the business.
categorization.financial_justification: The snippet mentions 'recognizes a provision' and 'not recorded a liability' for a financial obligation, indicating an acknowledgment of financial impact without providing a specific monetary value.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The obligation is tied to 'the end of its lease term' and 'upon decommissioning,' which are future events, but the current inability to estimate the cessation date makes the exact timeframe uncertain, hence 'Multiple or Unclear'.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that rising compliance, testing, registration, or re-registration costs related to their products is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: Changes in regulatory conditions in the markets in which we operate. Changes in laws, regulations, and the related interpretations may alter the environment in which we do business. This includes changes in governance, health and safety, competition and product-related laws and regulations, as well as changes in accounting standards and taxation requirements. This also includes the impact of proposed climate change-related regulations at both the international and national levels. Failure to comply with these laws may result in substantial fines, penalties, or other sanctions, such as the obligation to invest in newer equipment, permit revocations, or facility shutdowns. Consequently, we may experience delays in obtaining or be unable to obtain required permits, which may delay or interrupt our operations. In addition, global geopolitics have created uncertainty around tariff implementation in key markets, such as the EU and China, which may affect product or feedstock pricing.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 102, Regulatory Risks
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet identifies 'product-related laws and regulations' and the potential for 'delays in obtaining or be unable to obtain required permits' as risks. It also mentions 'obligation to invest in newer equipment' as a consequence of non-compliance, which implies rising costs associated with regulatory changes. While it doesn't explicitly state 'rising compliance, testing, registration, or re-registration costs' as a direct risk, it clearly outlines the regulatory environment and its potential cost implications for the business, thus providing a partial disclosure of the risk.

categorization.framing_justification: The language emphasizes potential negative consequences such as 'may alter the environment,' 'may result in substantial fines, penalties,' 'may experience delays,' and 'may interrupt our operations,' clearly framing these as threats to the business.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure mentions 'substantial fines, penalties' and 'obligation to invest in newer equipment,' which are financial impacts. However, no specific monetary values are provided, nor is a definitive statement of financial materiality for these specific cost types, qualifying it as partial-type.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet uses phrases like 'may alter,' 'may result in,' and 'may experience delays,' indicating potential future events and impacts, making it forward-looking.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that negative public perception of chemical-intensive agriculture, such as negative media articles, regulatory scrutiny or decreasing sales, is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: Changes in customer preferences, societal expectations, and the regulatory environment, resulting in decreased demand for our products and increased operational and environmental costs.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 18, Main Risks Across Our Operating Environment
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly identifies 'Changes in customer preferences, societal expectations' as a risk factor that directly results in 'decreased demand for our products.' This directly addresses the question of negative public perception (societal expectations) leading to market impact (decreasing sales).

categorization.framing_justification: The language 'resulting in decreased demand' and 'increased operational and environmental costs' clearly frames these changes as negative consequences or threats to the business, aligning with a 'Risk' framing.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure mentions 'decreased demand' and 'increased operational and environmental costs,' which are financial impacts, but it does not provide specific monetary values or explicitly state the financial materiality of these impacts.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The phrase 'resulting in' implies an ongoing or present-day impact from changes that have already occurred or are currently happening.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that high energy input costs due to the manufacture of its products is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: One of the Group’s subsidiaries, Sorfert Algérie SPA ("Sorfert"), operates under a 20-year natural gas supply contract with Sonatrach. The pricing for the gas was fixed for a period of 10 years and the initial period lapsed at the end of 2023. The new price shall be retrospectively applied from the lapse of the 10-year gas stability period. The Group is at an advanced stage of negotiation of the price with Sonatrach on the natural gas supply contract. The Group has recognised an estimated accrual of USD 182.8 million for the anticipated increase in gas cost as at 31 December 2024 based on the latest developments of the negotiation process and available information. The estimation of this accrual requires management to apply significant judgement including making assumptions and interpretation of the legal documents and correspondences regarding the final outcome of the negotiation. We consider this estimate to be a key audit matter due to the financial significance of the amounts involved and key judgments used by management.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 141, Independent auditor’s report to the shareholders of Fertiglobe plc
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet provides a clear and explicit disclosure about an 'anticipated increase in gas cost' for Sorfert, a key energy input, and states that the Group has 'recognised an estimated accrual of USD 182.8 million' for this. It further emphasizes the 'financial significance of the amounts involved.' This is a full disclosure as it identifies the risk (rising energy input costs) and provides a definitive statement about its financial materiality through a quantified accrual.

categorization.framing_justification: The phrase 'anticipated increase in gas cost' and the recognition of an 'accrual' for this increase clearly frame this as a negative financial event or threat to the business.
categorization.financial_justification: An explicit monetary value ('USD 182.8 million') is provided for the estimated accrual related to the increased gas cost, making it a financial disclosure.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The accrual is 'as at 31 December 2024,' reflecting a current financial position, even though the increase is 'anticipated' and 'retrospectively applied.' This makes it present day.

annotations.notes:
Duplicated in row 300.

This quote has more relevant context. Keep this row.

disclosures.quote: Geopolitical conflicts, including the war between Ukraine and Russia and in the Middle East, can have a direct and indirect impact on feedstock, fertilizer and food value chain. Over recent years, geopolitics has impacted gas and LNG availability and fertilizer production in key producing hubs, created shipping challenges across major export routes, as well as concerns around food security and grains exports. Such shocks and disruptions can impact the global supply and demand for gas, fertilizer and grains, as well as commodity prices and market sentiment.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 17, Geopolitics
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet identifies geopolitical conflicts as a factor that 'impacted gas and LNG availability' and 'commodity prices' for gas. Since natural gas is a key input for fertilizer production, this implicitly links geopolitical events to the risk of high energy input costs for manufacturing.

categorization.framing_justification: The language 'impacted gas and LNG availability' and 'shocks and disruptions can impact the global supply and demand for gas, fertilizer and grains, as well as commodity prices' clearly frames these as negative external factors and threats to the business.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure mentions 'commodity prices' for gas being impacted, which is a financial effect, but it does not provide specific monetary values or explicitly state the financial materiality of this impact on the company's energy input costs.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The phrase 'Over recent years, geopolitics has impacted' indicates past and ongoing effects, while 'can impact' suggests potential future impacts, making it a 'Multiple or Unclear' timeframe.

disclosures.quote: Slow transition from fossil fuels to clean energy sources. A continued dependence on fossil fuels and missed opportunities for investment in clean energy, increasing production cost, and loss of customers.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 18, Main Risks Across Our Operating Environment
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly states 'increasing production cost' as a risk resulting from 'continued dependence on fossil fuels.' This directly addresses the question of high energy input costs due to the manufacture of its products. It clearly identifies the risk but does not quantify its financial impact or explicitly state its materiality, thus it is a partial disclosure.

categorization.framing_justification: The language 'increasing production cost, and loss of customers' clearly frames this as a threat or negative consequence for the business.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure mentions 'increasing production cost,' indicating a financial impact without providing specific monetary values or a definitive statement of financial materiality. This aligns with a partial-type financial disclosure.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet describes a 'slow transition' and 'continued dependence' leading to future 'increasing production cost,' indicating a forward-looking timeframe.

disclosures.quote: Our products are global commodities with little or no product differentiation, and supply/demand dynamics can be affected by global trends, such as dietary patterns and population growth affecting demand for food, swings in crop and agricultural prices, global production capacity for our products, and the availability and pricing of the raw materials required to produce our products, particularly natural gas.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 98, Operational Risks - Changes to conditions affecting our markets and commodities
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly identifies 'the availability and pricing of the raw materials required to produce our products, particularly natural gas,' as a factor that can affect supply/demand dynamics. Given that natural gas is a key energy input for fertilizer manufacturing, this directly acknowledges high energy input costs as a business risk.

categorization.framing_justification: The statement describes factors that 'can be affected' and 'affect supply/demand dynamics,' implying potential negative impacts or challenges to the business, thus framing it as a 'Risk.'
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure mentions 'pricing of the raw materials' which is a financial aspect, but it does not provide specific monetary values or explicitly state the financial materiality of these pricing fluctuations.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The phrase 'can be affected' indicates potential future impacts, while the context of 'global trends' suggests ongoing relevance, leading to a 'Multiple or Unclear' timeframe.

disclosures.quote: In terms of the availability and cost of our key feedstock (natural gas), we manage our global exposure to natural gas price fluctuations through long-term contracts in the UAE, Egypt, and Algeria.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 98, Operational Risks - Changes to conditions affecting our markets and commodities - Risk Management Approach
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly states that 'the availability and cost of our key feedstock (natural gas)' is an exposure they 'manage,' confirming that high energy input costs (natural gas price fluctuations) are considered a risk to the business.

categorization.framing_justification: The statement acknowledges 'global exposure to natural gas price fluctuations' and describes management actions ('we manage'), framing this as a challenge or threat that requires mitigation, thus aligning with a 'Risk' framing.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure mentions 'cost' and 'price fluctuations' of natural gas, indicating a financial impact, but it does not provide specific monetary values or explicitly state the financial materiality of these fluctuations.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The phrase 'we manage our global exposure' implies an ongoing activity to address a present and potentially future risk.

disclosures.quote: We remain committed to operational efficiency and cost optimization. In 2023, we launched an ambitious initiative to improve our cost structure and reinforce our position as a low-cost producer. As of December 2024, we successfully achieved our annualized cost savings target of $50 million. Additionally, our Manufacturing Improvement Plan (MIP) is now 75% complete and is on track to unlock at least $100 million in incremental annual EBITDA by the end of 2025 by enhancing production and energy efficiency across our facilities.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 14, A Message from Our CEO
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly states the company's commitment to 'cost optimization' and 'energy efficiency' to 'unlock at least $100 million in incremental annual EBITDA by the end of 2025.' This clearly indicates that high energy input costs are a recognized business risk that the company is actively working to mitigate through efficiency improvements. The mention of a specific financial target ($100 million EBITDA) linked to energy efficiency demonstrates the financial significance of this area, but it's a target for improvement, not a statement of the risk's financial materiality itself. Thus, it is a partial disclosure.

categorization.framing_justification: The context of 'cost optimization' and the goal to 'unlock at least $100 million in incremental annual EBITDA' implies that current costs (including energy) are a challenge that needs to be addressed to improve profitability, framing it as a risk.
categorization.financial_justification: An explicit monetary value ('$100 million') is provided for the target incremental EBITDA linked to energy efficiency, making it a financial disclosure.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The phrase 'is on track to unlock... by the end of 2025' indicates future-oriented goals and benefits, making it forward-looking.

disclosures.quote: Our Commitment: We are committed to reducing our carbon footprint, and our Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions intensity are in line with our majority shareholder’s targets. We aim to achieve these reductions through a comprehensive climate strategy that includes investing in low-carbon technologies and projects and cooperating with all our stakeholders, industry peers, governments, and other institutions in the fight against climate change. In particular, our GHG reduction strategy is based on three pillars: • Operational excellence through a strong focus on energy efficiency and asset reliability, which results in a reduction in energy consumption and therefore reduces our reliance on fossil fuels and purchased energy, consequently reducing the intensity of our GHG emissions. • Transitioning our facilities to renewable energy sources (RES) through power purchase agreements (PPAs) and renewable energy certificates (RECs) for our purchased electricity (Scope 2). • New strategic, low-carbon, and renewable technologies that follow the transition pathway of blue and renewable, capitalizing on both new and established technologies, such as electrolysis, Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS), and purchased blue and renewable hydrogen.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 53, Energy and Climate Change
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet states that the company's GHG reduction strategy includes 'Operational excellence through a strong focus on energy efficiency and asset reliability, which results in a reduction in energy consumption and therefore reduces our reliance on fossil fuels and purchased energy.' This implicitly acknowledges that reliance on fossil fuels and purchased energy (which can lead to high input costs) is a concern that the company is actively trying to reduce. However, it does not explicitly state 'high energy input costs' as a risk or quantify its financial impact, making it unclear.

categorization.framing_justification: The focus is on 'reducing our carbon footprint' and 'reducing our reliance on fossil fuels and purchased energy' through strategic initiatives, which is a proactive management approach with environmental benefits, rather than explicitly framing high costs as a direct threat in this context.
categorization.financial_justification: No explicit financial amounts or statements of financial materiality are provided in this snippet.
categorization.timeframe_justification: Phrases like 'We aim to achieve,' 'includes investing,' 'Transitioning our facilities,' and 'New strategic, low-carbon, and renewable technologies' all point to future actions and goals, making it forward-looking.

disclosures.quote: Secure, long-term natural gas supply contracts and low-conversion costs further enhance Fertiglobe’s competitive standing on the global cost curve for ammonia and urea production.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 33, Our Facilities
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet highlights 'Secure, long-term natural gas supply contracts and low-conversion costs' as factors that 'further enhance Fertiglobe’s competitive standing.' By framing these as advantages, it implicitly acknowledges that insecure or high-cost natural gas supply (a key energy input) would be a risk to its competitive position. However, it does not explicitly state 'high energy input costs' as a risk to the business, making it unclear.

categorization.framing_justification: The language 'further enhance Fertiglobe’s competitive standing' frames the secure contracts as a positive factor or advantage for the company, thus an opportunity.
categorization.financial_justification: No explicit financial amounts or statements of financial materiality are provided in this snippet.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet describes existing contracts and their current benefit, indicating a present-day timeframe.

disclosures.quote: Moreover, we have taken concrete steps to limit the potential impact of future external events on our operations. These include the commissioning of a new boiler in Algeria, which will significantly improve our on-site power production through internally generated steam and reduce our reliance on the external power grid. We are also working on a water production improvement project in Egypt to enhance our resilience against potential external water supply issues.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 15, A Message from Our CEO - continued
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet describes 'concrete steps to limit the potential impact of future external events on our operations,' including commissioning a new boiler to 'reduce our reliance on the external power grid.' This implicitly acknowledges that reliance on the external power grid (and its associated costs or supply risks) is a concern for the business. It identifies a mitigation strategy but does not explicitly state 'high energy input costs' as a risk or quantify its financial impact, making it unclear.

categorization.framing_justification: The phrase 'limit the potential impact of future external events' implies that reliance on the external power grid is a vulnerability or threat that the company is addressing, framing it as a risk.
categorization.financial_justification: No explicit financial amounts or statements of financial materiality are provided in this snippet.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The phrases 'limit the potential impact of future external events' and 'will significantly improve' indicate future-oriented actions and benefits, making it forward-looking.

disclosures.quote: Energy Efficiency: • Energy-efficient designs featured by Fertiglobe’s young asset base. • Implemented monitoring tools to continuously improve energy consumption, supported by industry leading monitoring tools. • Reviewing our energy and feedstock purchases with the aim to increase our use of green or renewable sources, including increasing our purchase of renewable power (such as solar and wind energy) and increasing our consumption of biofuels and alternative green feedstocks. • Identify and pursue further efficiency through select value-accretive investments.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 54, Energy and Climate Change - continued
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet details the company's focus on 'Energy Efficiency' as part of its operational excellence program, including efforts to 'continuously improve energy consumption' and 'Reviewing our energy and feedstock purchases.' This implicitly acknowledges that energy consumption and associated costs are a significant operational concern that the company is actively managing. However, it does not explicitly state 'high energy input costs' as a risk or quantify its financial impact, making it unclear.

categorization.framing_justification: The focus is on 'Energy Efficiency' and 'continuously improve energy consumption,' which are proactive management strategies aimed at operational improvement, rather than explicitly framing high costs as a direct threat.
categorization.financial_justification: No explicit financial amounts or statements of financial materiality are provided in this snippet.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet describes ongoing efforts and implemented tools ('Implemented monitoring tools,' 'Reviewing our energy and feedstock purchases'), indicating a present-day timeframe.

disclosures.quote: The MIP aims to help to enhance operational reliability through capital projects and modernizing practices that minimize energy and water waste, paving the path toward more sustainable and renewable energy sources.
disclosures.source: Fertiglobe-Annual-Report-24-vF.pdf, Page 56, CASE STUDY Manufacturing Improvement Plan
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet states that the MIP aims to 'minimize energy and water waste.' While this is a positive operational goal related to efficiency, it does not explicitly state 'high energy input costs' as a risk to the business. It focuses on waste reduction and sustainability rather than the cost risk itself, making it unclear.

categorization.framing_justification: The language 'paving the path toward more sustainable and renewable energy sources' frames the minimization of waste as a positive development and an opportunity for the company.
categorization.financial_justification: No explicit financial amounts or statements of financial materiality are provided in this snippet.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The phrases 'aims to help to enhance' and 'paving the path toward' indicate future goals and developments, making it forward-looking.

analysis_results.question_text: Does the company disclose whether it thinks that agricultural crops developing resistance to its pesticides, which are applied by the company's customers to cropland, is a risk to the business?

disclosures.quote: Our growth efforts focus on developing environmentally compatible and sustainable solutions that can effectively increase farmers’ yields and provide alternatives to products which may be prone to resistance.
disclosures.source: FMC CORP files (ARS) Annual report to security holders (paper filing), for period end 31-Dec-24.pdf, Page 3, Business
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet acknowledges that some of FMC's products 'may be prone to resistance,' which directly identifies a characteristic of its products that poses a risk to their effectiveness and market viability.

categorization.framing_justification: The phrase 'products which may be prone to resistance' highlights a potential negative characteristic or vulnerability, framing it as a risk that the company seeks to address through alternatives.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure identifies a product characteristic that could lead to business challenges but does not provide any specific financial figures or explicit statements about financial materiality.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The focus on 'developing alternatives' and products 'may be prone' indicates a forward-looking perspective on potential future challenges.

annotations.notes: Risk is implicit.

disclosures.quote: Ambriva® herbicide... Phalaris minor... developed resistance to multiple herbicide chemistries, leaving farmers with limited options to protect their crops. Ambriva® herbicide has been rigorously tested on wheat over multiple seasons in India and has shown strong performance against Phalaris minor and key grass weeds already resistant to other modes of action. Sustainability Advantages of Isoflex™ active: › New mode of action in cereals (wheat and barley), providing farmers with a valuable tool for resistance management.
disclosures.source: FMC 2024 Sustainability Report_5.pdf, Page 15, Innovation for Agriculture
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet clearly identifies that weeds have 'developed resistance to multiple herbicide chemistries,' which leaves 'farmers with limited options.' FMC then positions its product, Ambriva® herbicide with Isoflex™ active, as a 'new mode of action' and a 'valuable tool for resistance management.' This implicitly acknowledges that crop resistance is a significant challenge for farmers, and by extension, a business challenge for FMC to address to remain competitive and provide effective solutions. However, the disclosure does not provide any statement about the financial materiality or immateriality of this risk to FMC.

categorization.framing_justification: The language 'developed resistance,' 'limited options,' and the emphasis on 'resistance management' frames the issue as a challenge or threat that needs to be addressed and managed by FMC's innovative solutions.
categorization.financial_justification: The snippet describes the impact of resistance and FMC's product as a solution but does not include any explicit financial figures or statements regarding financial materiality.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet describes an existing problem ('developed resistance') and FMC's current product offering ('providing farmers with a valuable tool'), indicating a present-day impact and response.

disclosures.quote: Adastrio® fungicide... combines fluindapyr, a novel molecule in the SDHI class of chemistry that controls pathogens resistant to other chemical classes... Sustainability Advantages of fluindapyr fungicide: › A novel molecule in the SDHI class to support resistance management.
disclosures.source: FMC 2024 Sustainability Report_5.pdf, Page 16, Innovation for Agriculture
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet highlights that FMC's Adastrio® fungicide 'controls pathogens resistant to other chemical classes' and offers a 'novel molecule... to support resistance management.' This demonstrates FMC's recognition of crop resistance as an existing problem that their products are designed to address, thereby implicitly acknowledging it as a business challenge. However, it does not provide any statement about the financial materiality or immateriality of this risk to FMC.

categorization.framing_justification: The focus on 'controls pathogens resistant' and 'support resistance management' frames the issue as a challenge or threat that FMC's products are designed to overcome.
categorization.financial_justification: The disclosure discusses product features and benefits related to resistance but does not provide any explicit financial figures or statements regarding financial materiality.
categorization.timeframe_justification: The snippet describes current product capabilities and their role in addressing existing resistance issues, indicating a present-day focus.

disclosures.quote: Overuse of insecticides to treat olive fruit fly infestations has led to the development of resistance, so an integrated approach is ideal.
disclosures.source: FMC 2024 Sustainability Report_5.pdf, Page 18, An Integrated Approach to Crop Protection
disclosures.classification_justification: This snippet explicitly states that 'overuse of insecticides... has led to the development of resistance,' clearly identifying crop resistance as a negative outcome. The subsequent recommendation of an 'integrated approach' implies that this resistance is a challenge that needs to be managed, and thus a risk to the business if not effectively addressed. However, the disclosure does not provide any statement about the financial materiality or immateriality of this risk to FMC.

categorization.framing_justification: The phrase 'has led to the development of resistance' highlights a negative consequence or threat that requires a strategic response.
categorization.financial_justification: The snippet describes the cause and effect of resistance and a proposed solution but does not include any explicit financial figures or statements regarding financial materiality.
categorization.timeframe_justification: While the development of resistance is a past event ('has led to'), the implication is that this resistance is a current condition that necessitates an 'integrated approach,' making the impact present day.

disclosures.quote: The Academy places particular emphasis on sustainable pest management and resistance management practices for controlling weeds, insects, and diseases.
disclosures.source: FMC 2024 Sustainability Report_5.pdf, Page 21, FMC Science Academy: Getting Closer to Growers

FMC works to identify, quantify, and mitigate risks related to product use and applies strict due diligence around products—including third-party products—that go to market. The Product Stewardship Framework guides work across the company and with customers, farmers, and industry partners. ... • Resistance Management
